While you are reviewing, one point I've heard others make about JUnit
is th=
at the ignore annotation is very much geared to giving the runner
an instru=
ction, not how the developer is expected to use it.

When using outside-in =
testingstyle it's quite common to "recurse" down
until you are at a point w=
hen you can actually implement something.
When you have arrived to that poi=
nt you have a trail of "pending"
tests that you activate one by one as you =
implement your way back to
the outer starting point. In that scenario, "pen=
ding" would be more in
line with how the developer uses JUnit.

I'll try to=
 illustrate:

winning hand is printed first : pending - We need to find the=
 kicker
when two hands are the same
highest card wins of two complete hands=
: failed
complete hand is detected: pass
fold is detected: pass

The above =
was not testdriven, in reality the tests might be different
but I hope it i=
llustrates my point, the first test written is at the
top. I view it as a "=
stack" and we have started to "roll back" by
making the two bottommost test=
s pass and just removed @pending("we
need to be able to detect complete han=
d") from the "second" test.

Another related extremely cool feature would b=
e if like with rspec, an
empty test-body would automatically become pending=
 (have no idea how I
would solve that... A test that does not make any asse=
rts?).

Perhaps also a pending-block:
new Pending("I need to implement the =
other stuff before something
useful is done here") {{
    assertThat(someth=
ing, is("something useful"));
}};
Would go from "pending" to "fixed" when t=
he assertion passes which
signals that you can remove the pending-block.

I=
 understand that this is mostly "sugar" and that the verdict may be
that it=
 would violate JUnit's "intersection" philosophy but I thought
there would =
be no harm in expressing my whishes, right?

Best regards,
Joakim Ohlrogge
